00075 using namespace phys;
00076 
00077 namespace phys
00078 {
00079     class PhysMotionState;
00080     ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00081     /// @class ActorBase
00082     /// @headerfile physactor.h
00083     /// @brief This is the base class from which all the actors inherit.
00084     /// @details The actor classes store and manage all the relevant data regarding
00085     /// objects inside the World.  They serve as a binder between the physics and
00086     /// graphics for objects and have functions that allow the manipulation of objects
00087     /// loaded into the World.  Currently there are 4 actor classes: ActorBase,
00088     /// ActorDynRigid, ActorDynSoft, and ActorSta. @n
00089     /// ActorBase is a base class that serves as a template for the other three actor classes. @n
00090     /// ActorBase should never be created, as it lacks the functionality needed for most objects.
00091     ///////////////////////////////////////
00092     class ActorBase {
00093         private:
00094             friend class phys::World;
00095 
00096         protected:
00097 
00098             World* GameWorld;
00099 
00100             //abstraction for other libraries
00101             Ogre::Entity* entity;
00102             Ogre::SceneNode* node;
00103 
00104             btCollisionShape* Shape;
00105             btCollisionObject* CollisionObject;
00106 
00107             PhysMotionState* MotionState;
00108 
00109             /// @brief Adds the actor to the physics world.
00110             /// @details Adds the actor to the physics world. @n
00111             /// This is automaticly called by the PhysWorlds AddActor function and shouldn't be called manually.
00112             /// @param TargetWorld Pointer to the World class.
00113             /// @param btWorld Pointer to the physics world.
00114             virtual void AddObjectToWorld(World* TargetWorld, btSoftRigidDynamicsWorld* btWorld) = 0;
00115             /// @brief Creates a trimesh shape from the mesh file.
00116             /// @details Makes a trimesh to be used as a collision shape in the physics world from a mesh file. @n
00117             /// This is automaticly called by the CreateShapeFromMesh function in child classes and shouldn't be called manually.
00118             void CreateTrimesh();
00119 
00120             //Ogre Management Functions
00121             /// @brief Creates an entity for the mesh file to be placed on a scene node.
00122             /// @details Creates an entity in the scene manager from the mesh file provided to be attached to a node in the graphical world. @n
00123             /// This function is called on by the Constructor, and shouldn't be called manually.
00124             /// @param Name Name of the actor.
00125             /// @param File File name of the graphical mesh to be used.
00126             /// @param Group Resource group where the graphical mesh can be found.
00127             void CreateEntity(String name, String file, String group);
00128             /// @brief Creates a node for the entity in the graphical world.
00129             /// @details Creates a node in the scene manager to attach the actor's entity to within the graphical world. @n
00130             /// This function is called on by the Constructor, and shouldn't be called manually.
00131             void CreateSceneNode();
00132             /// @brief Sets the location of the graphical body.
00133             /// @details This will take a PhysVector3 and set the location of the actor within the graphical world. @n
00134             /// This function is called on by the SetLocation function, and shouldn't be called manually.
00135             /// @param Location The PhysVector3 representing the location.
00136             void SetOgreLocation(PhysVector3 Place);
00137             /// @brief Retrieves the location of the graphical body.
00138             /// @details This function will retrieve the location of the object within the graphical world.
00139             PhysVector3 GetOgreLocation();
00140             /// @brief Sets the orientation of the graphical body.
00141             /// @details This will take a PhysQuaternion and set the orientation of the actor within the graphical world. @n
00142             /// This function is called on by the SetOrientation function, and shouldn't be called manually.
00143             /// @param Rotation The quaternion representing the rotation of the actor.
00144             void SetOgreOrientation (Quaternion Rotation);
00145             /// @brief Makes the actor visable.
00146             /// @details Adds the actor to all the nessessary graphics elements to make it visable on screen. @n
00147             /// This is automaticly called by the PhysWorlds AddActor function and shouldn't ever need to be called manually.
00148             void AttachToGraphics();
00149 
00150             //Bullet Management
00151             /// @brief Sets the location of the physics body.
00152             /// @details This will take a PhysVector3 and set the location of the actor within the physics world. @n
00153             /// This function is called on by the SetLocation function, and shouldn't be called manually.
00154             /// @param Location The PhysVector3 representing the location.
00155             virtual void SetBulletLocation (PhysVector3 Location);
00156             /// @brief Retrieves the location of the physics body.
00157             /// @details This function will retrieve the location of the object within the physics world.
00158             virtual PhysVector3 GetBulletLocation();
00159             /// @brief Sets the starting location of the physics body within the PhysMotionState.
00160             /// @details Sets the starting location of the physics body within the PhysMotionState. @n
00161             /// This function is called on by the SetInitLocation function, and shouldn't be called manually.
00162             /// @param Location The PhysVector3 representing the desired starting location for the actor.
00163             void SetBulletInitLocation (PhysVector3 Location);
00164             /// @brief Sets the orientation of the physics body.
00165             /// @details This will take a PhysQuaternion and set the orientation of the actor within the physics world. @n
00166             /// This function is called on by the SetOrientation function, and shouldn't be called manually.
00167             /// @param Rotation The quaternion representing the rotation of the actor.
00168             virtual void SetBulletOrientation (Quaternion Rotation);
00169 
00170         public:
00171             /// @brief Destructor.
00172             /// @details The class destructor.
00173             virtual ~ActorBase ();
00174             /// @brief Descriptive constructor.
00175             /// @details This constructor contains the basic information needed to make an actor.
00176             /// @param Name The name of the actor.
00177             /// @param File The 3d mesh file that contains the 3d model the actor will use.
00178             /// @param Group The resource group where the 3d mesh and other related files can be found.
00179             /// @param _World Pointer to the World this object will be added to.
00180             ActorBase (String name, String file, String group, World* _World);
00181 
00182             /// @brief Manually sets the location of the actor.
00183             /// @details Calling this function prior to adding it to the World will have no effect. @n
00184             /// In most situations you won't want to use this function, and instead produce movement through physics functions.
00185             /// @param X Location on the X vector.
00186             /// @param Y Location on the Y vector.
00187             /// @param Z Location on the Z vector.
00188             void SetLocation(Real x, Real y, Real z);
00189             /// @brief Manually sets the location of the actor.
00190             /// @details Calling this function prior to adding it to the World will have no effect. @n
00191             /// In most situations you won't want to use this function, and instead produce movement through physics functions.
00192             /// @param Place The PhysVector3 representing the location.
00193             void SetLocation(PhysVector3 Place);
00194             /// @brief Retrieves the location of the object.
00195             /// @details This function will retrieve the location of the object within the world.
00196             PhysVector3 GetLocation();
00197 
00198             /// @brief Sets the starting location of the actor.
00199             /// @details Calling this function after adding it to the World will have no effect. @n
00200             /// This function will set where the actor will be located in the World when it is first placed inside the world.
00201             /// @param Location The PhysVector3 representing the location.
00202             void SetInitLocation(PhysVector3 Location);
00203             /// @brief Sets the starting orientation of the actor.
00204             /// @details Calling this function after adding it to the World will have no effect. @n
00205             /// This function will set where the actor is facing in the World when it is first placed inside the world.
00206             /// @param Orientation The PhysQuaternion representing the Orientation.
00207             void SetInitOrientation(Quaternion Orientation);
00208 
00209             /// @brief Sets the orientation of the actor.
00210             /// @details Sets the orientation of the actor via Quaternion parameters.
00211             void SetOrientation(Real x, Real y, Real z, Real w);
00212             /// @brief Sets the orientation of the actor.
00213             /// @details Sets the orientation of the actor via a Quaternion.
00214             /// @param Rotation The Quaternion representing the Rotation.
00215             void SetOrientation(Quaternion Rotation);
00216 
00217             /// @brief Sets the state of the object to Kinematic.
00218             /// @details This function will set the object to a Kinematic Object. @n
00219             /// Kinematic Objects are like Static Objects but are also able to be moved directly by character controllers.
00220             void SetKinematic();
00221             /// @brief Sets the state of the object to Static.
00222             /// @details This function will set the object to a Static Object. @n
00223             /// Static Objects don't move or have any force applied to them, but are cabable of exerting force on other objects.
00224             void SetStatic();
00225     };
00226 
00227     ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00228     /// @class ActorRigid
00229     /// @headerfile physactor.h
00230     /// @brief This is the actor class for Rigid Objects.
00231     /// @details This class should be used to make any rigid object that can be moved as a
00232     /// result of force.  Most objects will fall into this catagory.  A few examples of a
00233     /// Rigid Object: Boxes, Car Frames, Chairs, etc.  For Semi Rigid bodies that are
00234     /// deformable, like jello, it is better to use ActorSoft.
00235     ///////////////////////////////////////
00236 
00237     class ActorRigid: public ActorBase {
00238 
00239         protected:
00240             btRigidBody* physrigidbody;
00241             /// @brief Creates a rigid object for the actor.
00242             /// @details Creates a rigid object to be placed in the physics world later. @n
00243             /// This is automaticly called by the Constructor and shouldn't be called manually.
00244             /// @param PMass "Real Mass" The mass of the object.
00245             void CreateRigidObject (Real pmass);
00246             /// @brief Adds the actor to the physics world.
00247             /// @details Adds the actor to the physics world. @n
00248             /// This is automaticly called by the PhysWorlds AddActor function and shouldn't be called manually.
00249             /// @param TargetWorld Pointer to the World class.
00250             /// @param btWorld Pointer to the physics world.
00251             void AddObjectToWorld (World *TargetWorld, btSoftRigidDynamicsWorld* btWorld);
00252 
00253         public:
00254             /// @brief Descriptive constructor.
00255             /// @details This constructor contains the basic information needed to make a Rigid Object. @n
00256             /// This class inherits from ActorBase.
00257             /// @param Mass The mass the object will have in the World.
00258             /// @param Name The name of the actor.
00259             /// @param File The 3d mesh file that contains the 3d model the actor will use.
00260             /// @param Group The resource group where the 3d mesh and other related files can be found.
00261             /// @param _World Pointer to the World this object will be added to.
00262             ActorRigid(Real mass, String name, String file, String group, World* _World);
00263             /// @brief Destructor.
00264             /// @details The class destructor.
00265             virtual ~ActorRigid();
00266             /// @brief Creates a collision shape from mesh file.
00267             /// @details This function will read the location of every verticy in the mesh file and use that to
00268             /// construct a triangle mesh shape and attach it to this objects collision shape.
00269             void CreateShapeFromMesh();
00270     };
00271 
00272     ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00273     /// @class ActorSoft
00274     /// @headerfile physactor.h
00275     /// @brief This is the actor class for Soft Objects.
00276     /// @details This class should be used to make any soft object that, like ActorRigid,
00277     /// can be moved or manipulated as a result of force.  Examples of soft objects are: Paper,
00278     /// Rope, and Cloth.  Semi Rigid bodies that are still somewhat deformable, like Jello,
00279     /// should be made as a soft object.
00280     ///////////////////////////////////////
00281 
00282     class ActorSoft: public ActorBase {
00283 
00284         protected:
00285             btSoftBody* physsoftbody;
00286             /// @brief Creates a soft object for the actor.
00287             /// @details Creates a soft object to be placed in the physics world later. @n
00288             /// This is automaticly called by the Constructor and shouldn't be called manually.
00289             void CreateSoftObject (btSoftBodyWorldInfo* softworldinfo, int nodecount, btVector3* nodearray, btScalar* massarray);
00290             /// @brief Adds the actor to the physics world.
00291             /// @details Adds the actor to the physics world. @n
00292             /// This is automaticly called by the PhysWorlds AddActor function and shouldn't be called manually.
00293             /// @param TargetWorld Pointer to the World class.
00294             /// @param btWorld Pointer to the physics world.
00295             void AddObjectToWorld (World *TargetWorld, btSoftRigidDynamicsWorld* btWorld);
00296 
00297         public:
00298             ActorSoft();
00299             /// @brief Destructor.
00300             /// @details The class destructor.
00301             virtual ~ActorSoft();
00302             /// @brief Creates a collision shape from mesh file.
00303             /// @details This function will read the location of every verticy in the mesh file and use that to
00304             /// construct a triangle mesh shape and attach it to this objects collision shape.
00305             void CreateShapeFromMesh();
00306     };
00307 }
00308 #endif
